segments.text: a different situation had taken place.
When I came back immediately after 1951, I had an offer to come as visiting professor to University of North Carolina in Raleigh, as well as Chapel Hill.
And I had an offer to maybe take over the program there
in the School of Architecture, but they had already a very, very good planning program in Chapel Hill with Jack Parker.
And so I went back and forth, but while I was there, I met the Vice Chancellor of North Carolina, who had just become the Chancellor of the University of Texas.
So when I came back here, he came back, and we had already a working relationship, and he supported me quite
vociferously, sending me to the various meetings on the Southern Regional Education Board, which we tried to join, but there was an enormous opposition.
Texas has a certain aversion to join other regions.
And so Wilson Logan
or Logan Wilson, could not do anything.

But he set up two committees, one committee under his own guidance, you may say, consisting of various people from all involved, law, for instance, or engineering, or whatever, and another one, a working committee, the Graduate Studies Committee, also consisting of the chairman of various groups and professors in sociology and economics,
engineering and so forth.
Mr. Gleuner, for instance, Dr. Gleuner, who is now the Dean of College of Engineering.
How does he spell his name?
Gleuner, G-L-O-Y-N-E, Gleuner.
And they had all established planning in their departments, which is, of course, a very good thing.
But it didn't work out in our case.
In fact, reasonable planning was resented by people in economics,

And as a side remark, I just want to mention that at that time, probably already, the ideas of the LBJ, the Institute of Public Affairs, was going around, but of course nobody could talk about these things, so we were still encouraged to go on our way, but the administration's heart was no longer in it.
And so when we finally, in 1959,
got the official permission of the coordinating board.
By that time, they all had left and went their own way.
And it was a pretty hard struggle from then on.
So we had a small program within architecture.
And it was a period of struggle.
But we had a small number of people who went through this.
By that time, I had reached retirement age.
we had new people coming in and from then on the whole thing took off.
So I just want to talk up to that point.
Actually, in connection with a German film on the redevelopment of the Ruhr,
area in Western Germany, along the Rhine and the Ruhr, a film was made, which I produced here several times.
And in that connection, a discussion took place in New York, where they talked about the difficulties which
They're quite obvious in my efforts here, but they're also quite universal over the United States.
And I just wanted to quote something here because it has to do with an understanding of the difficulties elsewhere, I imagine.
But anyway, in this discussion in New York, a speaker commented on why Americans have a bias toward planning.
The speaker made much of the impossibility of transferring cultural values from Europe to the United States.
The speaker, a woman, pointed out that Americans have an anti-historical bias in the total culture, irrespective of where they come from originally.
That prevents them from implementing any planning program, especially in the northeastern cities of the United States.
In fact,
In New York, Boston, and so on, European principles of town planning cannot be applied at all, either physically or administratively.
Well, I just want to put that in because that explains a lot of the difficulties, you know, which are part of the, you may say, the sentiment, you know, the general sentiment.
So when I say I had a struggle, it is really nothing unusual.
No, not at all.
Except I didn't know all these things.
All right.
But there was a lot of European influence, nevertheless.
Oh, yes.
Particularly eastern cities, in terms of their early planning programs.
Not so much in the Middle West or the Far West, because we were too isolated from Europe.
But it was much easier for a person living in Boston or New York to get to Europe than it was for him to get to Texas or California, even.
Well, Bob, you're absolutely right.
Because when I mentioned at the beginning of our interview the Rockefeller grant, which I received, and the $80,000 each given to Harvard, MIT, and Columbia University, what they do with the money.
Columbia University got Raymond Unwin from England.
MIT got Father and Son, the Englishman, who was chairman of the department for quite a while.
We'll fill that in later.
Yeah, on the conscription.
Adams, Mr. Adams.
Oh, yes, yes.
Frederick Adams.
Frederick, our father.
with a regional plan, New York, you know, and his son, who became chairman of MIT, of MIT, the planning program.
So, I mean, this illustrates that the European influence was very strong up to that point, and then it sort of broke down and away from it.
But during the 1910s and 1920s, it was fantastic, the European influence, especially French, and to some degree German, through the districting or zoning in German cities.
But that didn't really transmit very much to the Middle West or West.
Well, it took actually...
Except for people like you.
No, no, no, no, no, no, no.
That's incidental.
No, it really is evident in Texas.
You know, Colonel Kessler.
I have written that all down because it is... George Kessler?
Was it George Kessler?
From Kansas City?
Yes, of course.
He was the one that did the incredible park system for Kansas City and worked in Dallas and Fort Worth.
As well as El Paso.
But he was educated in Germany.
We're not quite sure if he was born in Germany and raised in Dallas, and then his mother took him back to Germany for his education later on.
But we're not quite sure if he was born in Germany or not.
Bob, in 1965, Martha and I were asked to write a... summarize what we knew about the history of planning in Texas up to that time.
So that was done for the League of Women Voters of Texas.
And it may have some pertinent stuff in there.
You were just talking about Kessler and...
Of course, we know that he worked in Fort Worth, in Dallas, and I believe also in El Paso.
Yes.
He did a plan in 1925 in El Paso.
Yes.
And this is here sort of a rundown of these various efforts, which, of course, is no longer up to date.
It is only...
taking in the area prior to the development as we know it now.
Why is it that the University of Texas planning program has never achieved separate departmental status?
They have their own faculty,

they control their own budget why is it that they don't have you know a clear departmental status within the university structure well bob this is a very complex situation the university of texas of course now it's a systems university but has a very large

uh... budgetary setup i mean a very large commitment to spend their monies and uh... they don't like to deal with small entities in other words uh... let's say the college of arts and sciences is an enormous thing that was broken down into colleges into different colleges to take the sciences and the arts
Separately.
Now, the School of Architecture was a school within the College of Engineering.
It was a department, actually, together with the other eight or ten or twelve departments.
And as such, they took an administrative unit through the dean to the president.

And of course the administration is not too much impressed by small units which have really not much of a backing, financial backing, such as law or medicine or even economics or business administration, you know.
And that has been actually the main reason.
So the struggle we had was constantly to get our share within a larger budget.
And maybe that isn't such a bad idea because you really have to exert yourself.
You have to show.
Now, the whole system is based on student enrollment and graduate numbers.
And since our program has never been very large,
it didn't seem to make too much sense to the administration.

And in addition to this, the whole field of planning, as defined by the American Institute of Planners at the time, through their accrediting board, became very, very stringent in their requirements, which today is no longer the case.
And once we had fulfilled one set of requirements, they had added others.
And as a result, we never quite made it until...
We got Mr. Cole, who had very good input in Washington, having been with the Transportation Administration.
And through his effort, he had received pretty large research grants prior to coming.
Afterwards, it was no longer the case to such an extent.
So by looking at it this way, they felt that there was really a lot of pressure from the outside, because the Americans are planners.
The Texas chapter made numerous efforts.
We brought in just about everybody from Mosseen, who was president of AIP, to Paul Oppermann, who was president of MIT, to Cusick, who was president of AIP.
We had all these people here.
They made all efforts, but to no avail.
And so it was one of these things.
And of course, today, in retrospect, the situation is different again.
so that, as is the case probably in any discipline, changes take place and they make past efforts in retrospect seem rather futile.
In connection with this, we made enormous efforts not only to bring the various succeeding presidents of national AIP to Austin to participate in conferences and talk to the
chancellor, president, and the dean of officials and so forth.
But we also attempted to get monies from the Ford Foundation, which gave enormous amounts of money to any number of universities to set up departments, independent departments with their own budgets.
And so to think in terms of the millions, scores of millions of dollars that went into University of Wisconsin or, of course, Harvard, MIT, Columbia, Tennessee, you name it.
I mean, any number of places didn't seem to make too much difference to our administration.
I personally had the permission of the then Vice President Ransom to talk to people at the...

Ford Foundation in New York, and that didn't help either much, because there were too many competing areas on this campus here that wanted money from the Ford Foundation, that we were just sort of a nuisance in this whole effort.
So I went and got monies from the coordinating board for Texas colleges.
What was it, under Title I of the Education Act?
and also through my activities with the Urban Planning Assistance Program, 701, where we could channel monies to research work and so forth.
When I was serving as a consultant to the United States High Commissioner for Germany, I received a note from the organizer of the first post-World War II planning
exhibit and conference where the American exhibit was.
That was in May or June 1950.
The conference was supposed to be in the fall in Amsterdam.
But there wasn't anything.
It happened to fall between two chairs, namely the chair of Mr. Adams
who was president of AAP at MIT, and Mr. Paul Oppermann, who has been the new president of AAP, who was in San Francisco at that time.
Between the two, nothing had happened.
So I wrote a blistering critique about this whole thing that among all the nations in the world, the United States was not represented.
And the High Commissioner for Germany said, we have to get something there.
Why don't you build something?
I said, that's impossible.
It takes much more.
You have to have a story and so forth.
So we said, okay, we have to have something.

So I got the standard equipment on housing and planning, which every embassy has, which consists of three filing cabinets, steel filing cabinets, and a table full of planning literature, which was the representation of the United States, while London had a huge model about 12 feet high with all the burning things to be reconstructed over London and, you know, that style.
So that same year,
I had a call from when I came back in 50 for a few months.
I had a call from Washington saying, well, when can you have that exhibit ready?
I said, what exhibit?
Well, you criticize that we didn't have an exhibit.
Can you build one now?
I said, yes, of course.
So here I was.
And within two months, I had to set up an exhibit of American post-war planning efforts.
So with the stationery from the State Department in Washington, I wrote to Mr. Bob Moses in New York, to people in Seattle, to people in anywhere, everywhere, big cities.
And over the weekends, I went to these cities and got all their material, and we built here in Austin, Texas, School of Architecture.
We built that exhibit, 600 pounds of it, and sent it over by airmail.
And then I went back to Germany, and it was in Hanover, and went over the whole of Germany and England.
so that is an interesting thing I still have all that material so one can see what we did if it's on loose or whatever you know yeah
